clinical_condition: Post-NSTEMI Status, Coronary Artery Disease with PCI

qualifying_diagnoses: Percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with stent placement
Chronic heart failure with reduced ejection fraction
medical_necessity_criteria: Documented cardiovascular diagnosis meeting coverage indications
Patient is medically stable for outpatient exercise program
Physician referral and prescription for cardiac rehabilitation
Expected benefit from structured cardiac rehabilitation program

coverage_decision_case_008.qualifying_diagnosis: NSTEMI (I21.4) with PCI and drug-eluting stent placement

clinical_findings.PCI_performed: Yes - Stents to left circumflex and RCA

rationale: Recent NSTEMI (within 12 months) - meets qualifying diagnosis
Successful PCI with dual drug-eluting stent placement to obtuse marginal and RCA
Patient medically stable post-procedure for outpatient rehabilitation
Multiple cardiac risk factors requiring modification (HTN, dyslipidemia, CKD)
Preserved ejection fraction indicates good candidate for exercise-based rehabilitation
Physician referral with clear medical necessity documentation
Evidence-based guidelines (AHA/ACC) strongly recommend cardiac rehab post-MI with PCI
Expected to benefit from structured program for secondary prevention

expected_outcomes.functional_capacity: Improved exercise tolerance and quality of life
expected_outcomes.risk_factor_modification: Better control of hypertension, lipids, and diabetes

clinical_guidelines_applied: AHA/ACC Guidelines for Cardiac Rehabilitation and Secondary Prevention (2024)
AACVPR Guidelines for Cardiac Rehabilitation Programs (2023)
CMS National Coverage Determination (NCD) 20.10 - Cardiac Rehabilitation Programs
Ambetter Medical Policy: Cardiac Rehabilitation Services Coverage Criteria
evidence_summary: Meta-analyses of randomized controlled trials demonstrate that cardiac rehabilitation after MI reduces all-cause mortality by 20-30%, improves functional capacity, enhances quality of life, and provides cost-effective secondary prevention. Current guidelines give Class I recommendation (strong evidence) for cardiac rehab post-PCI.
